entry.title: The Navier-Stokes equations in vector calculus notation, Einstein notation, and Cartesian components

link.title: The Navier-Stokes equations in vector calculus notation, Einstein notation, and Cartesian components

entry.content:
Introduction

In this post, I will give several important equations in fluid mechanics in three forms: vector calculus notation, Einstein notation, and with the Cartesian components written out. The purpose of this post is for education. I find is much easier to understand different forms and notations of the equations when they are written side-by-side, and derived sequentially. In particular, seeing the Einstein/index/tensor notation and Cartesian components side-by-side is helpful in learning Einstein notation.

References I used to compile this post:

  1. Çengel and Cimbala, Fluid Mechanics: Fundamentals and Applications, McGraw Hill, 4th Edition.
  2. Pope, Turbulent Flows, Cambridge University Press.
  3. Wikipedia Page on Navier-Stokes Equations

Prerequisites

Format

The format is as follows:

Quantity

\[ ext{Vector calculus notation}\] \[ ext{Einstein notation}\] \[ ext{Cartesian components}\]

Tensors

Vector (rank 1 tensor)

\[\vec{a}\] \[a_i\] \[ egin{bmatrix} a_x\ a_y\ a_z \end{bmatrix}\]

Velocity vector

\[\vec{V}\] \[v_i\] \[ egin{bmatrix} u\ v\ w \end{bmatrix}\]

Matrix (rank 2 tensor)

\[A\] \[A_{ij}\] \[ egin{bmatrix} A_{xx} & A_{xy} & A_{xz}\ A_{yx} & A_{yy} & A_{yz}\ A_{zx} & A_{zy} & A_{zz} \end{bmatrix}\]

Identity matrix

\[I\] \[\delta_{ij}\] \[ egin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0\ 0 & 1 & 0\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}\]

Operations

Dot product (inner product)

\[\vec{a}\cdot \vec{b}\] \[a_i b_i\] \[a_x b_x + a_y b_y + a_z b_z\]

Divergence of a vector

\[\vec{ abla}\cdot \vec{a}\] \[ rac{\partial a_i}{\partial x_i}\] \[ rac{\partial a_x}{\partial x} + rac{\partial a_y}{\partial y} + rac{\partial a_z}{\partial z}\]

Vector-matrix product

\[\vec{a}\cdot B\] \[a_i B_{ij}\] \[ egin{bmatrix} a_x B_{xx} & a_yB_{xy} & a_zB_{xz}\ a_x B_{yx} & a_yB_{yy} & a_zB_{yz}\ a_x B_{zx} & a_yB_{zy} & a_zB_{zz} \end{bmatrix}\]

Divergence of a tensor

\[\vec{ abla}\cdot A\] \[ rac{\partial A_{ij}}{\partial x_i}\] \[ egin{bmatrix} rac{\partial B_{xx}}{\partial x} + rac{\partial B_{yx}}{\partial y} + rac{\partial B_{zx}}{\partial z}\ rac{\partial B_{xy}}{\partial x} + rac{\partial B_{yy}}{\partial y} + rac{\partial B_{zy}}{\partial z}\ rac{\partial B_{xz}}{\partial x} + rac{\partial B_{yz}}{\partial y} + rac{\partial B_{zz}}{\partial z} \end{bmatrix}\]

Tensor product or outer product

\[\vec{a}\vec{b} \equiv \vec{a}\otimes\vec{b}\] \[a_i b_j\] \[ egin{bmatrix} a_x b_x & a_x b_y & a_x b_z \ a_y b_x & a_y b_y & a_y b_z \ a_z b_x & a_z b_y & a_z b_z \end{bmatrix}\]

Gradient of a vector

\[\vec{ abla} \vec{a}\] \[ rac{\partial a_i}{\partial x_j}\] \[ egin{bmatrix} rac{\partial a_x}{\partial x} & rac{\partial a_x}{\partial y} & rac{\partial a_x}{\partial z} \ rac{\partial a_y}{\partial x} & rac{\partial a_y}{\partial y} & rac{\partial a_y}{\partial z}\ rac{\partial a_z}{\partial x} & rac{\partial a_z}{\partial y} & rac{\partial a_z}{\partial z} \end{bmatrix}\]

Equations in fluid mechanics

We start with Cauchy’s equation, then expand the various terms to arrive at the compressible Navier-Stokes equations. After assuming constant density, we arrive at the incompressible Navier-Stokes equations.

Important definitions

Material derivative of velocity

The material derivative operator is notated as \( ho D()/Dt\). The material derivative of velocity appears frequently.

\[ rac{D\vec{V}}{Dt} = rac{\partial\vec{V}}{\partial t}+(\vec{V}\cdot \vec{ abla})\vec{V}\] \[ rac{Dv_j}{Dt} = rac{\partial v_j}{\partial t} +v_i rac{\partial v_j}{\partial x_i}\] \[ egin{align*} rac{Du}{Dt} &= rac{\partial u}{\partial t} + u rac{\partial u}{\partial x} + v rac{\partial u}{\partial y} + w rac{\partial u}{\partial z}\ rac{Dv}{Dt} &= rac{\partial v}{\partial t} + u rac{\partial v}{\partial x} + v rac{\partial v}{\partial y} + w rac{\partial v}{\partial z}\ rac{Dw}{Dt} &= rac{\partial w}{\partial t} + u rac{\partial w}{\partial x} + v rac{\partial w}{\partial y} + w rac{\partial w}{\partial z} \end{align*}\]

Stress tensor

The Cauchy stress tensor is made up of isotropic (hydrostatic) stress, from pressure, and anisotropic (deviatoric) stress, from viscous forces.

\[\sigma = -P I + au\] \[\sigma_{ij}= -P\delta_{ij} + au_{ij}\] \[\sigma = - egin{bmatrix}P & 0 & 0\ 0 & P & 0\0 & 0 & P \end{bmatrix} + egin{bmatrix} au_{xx} & au_{xy} & au_{xz} \ au_{yx} & au_{yy} & au_{yz} \ au_{zx} & au_{zy} & au_{zz}\end{bmatrix}\]

Viscous stress tensor

This is the constitutive relation describing how shear is converted to a viscous stress. \(\zeta\) is the second viscosity or bulk viscosity of the fluid, and is usually assumed to be zero. \(\mu\) is the dynamic viscosity. Shown here is a linear relationship (Newtonian fluid).

\[ au = \zeta (\vec{ abla}\cdot \vec{V})I + \mu [\vec{ abla}\vec{V} + (\vec{ abla}\vec{V})^ ext{T} - frac{2}{3}(\vec{ abla} \cdot \vec{V})I ]\] \[ au_{ij} = \zeta rac{\partial v_k}{\partial x_k}\delta_{ij} + \mu \left[ rac{\partial v_j}{\partial x_i} + rac{\partial v_i}{\partial x_j} - rac{2}{3} rac{\partial v_k}{\partial x_k} \delta_{ij} ight]\] \[ egin{align*} au = &\zeta egin{bmatrix} \left( rac{\partial u}{\partial x} + rac{\partial v}{\partial y} + rac{\partial w}{\partial z} ight) & 0 & 0 \ 0 & \left( rac{\partial u}{\partial x} + rac{\partial v}{\partial y} + rac{\partial w}{\partial z} ight) & 0 \ 0 & 0 & \left( rac{\partial u}{\partial x} + rac{\partial v}{\partial y} + rac{\partial w}{\partial z} ight) \end{bmatrix} \ &+ \mu egin{bmatrix} 2 rac{\partial u}{\partial x} - rac{2}{3}\left( rac{\partial u}{\partial x} + rac{\partial v}{\partial y} + rac{\partial w}{\partial z} ight) & rac{\partial v}{\partial x} + rac{\partial u}{\partial y} & rac{\partial w}{\partial x} + rac{\partial u}{\partial z} \ rac{\partial u}{\partial y} + rac{\partial v}{\partial x} & 2 rac{\partial v}{\partial y} - rac{2}{3}\left( rac{\partial u}{\partial x} + rac{\partial v}{\partial y} + rac{\partial w}{\partial z} ight) & rac{\partial w}{\partial y} + rac{\partial v}{\partial z} \ rac{\partial u}{\partial z} + rac{\partial w}{\partial x} & rac{\partial v}{\partial z} + rac{\partial w}{\partial y} & 2 rac{\partial w}{\partial z} - rac{2}{3}\left( rac{\partial u}{\partial x} + rac{\partial v}{\partial y} + rac{\partial w}{\partial z} ight) \end{bmatrix} \end{align*}\]

Compressible continuity equation

\[ rac{\partial ho}{\partial t} + \vec{ abla} \cdot ( ho \vec{V}) = 0\] \[ rac{\partial ho}{\partial t} + rac{\partial ( ho v_j)}{\partial x_j} = 0\] \[ rac{\partial ho}{\partial t} + rac{\partial( ho u)}{\partial x} + rac{\partial ( ho v)}{\partial y} + rac{\partial ( ho w)}{\partial z} = 0\]

Incompressible continuity equation

Assumes \( ho\) is constant.

\[\vec{ abla} \cdot \vec{V} = 0\] \[ rac{\partial v_j}{\partial x_j} = 0\] \[ rac{\partial u}{\partial x} + rac{\partial v}{\partial y} + rac{\partial w}{\partial z} = 0\]

Cauchy’s equation

General equation for momentum transport in a continuum. Here, we consider gravity as the only body force.

\[ rac{\partial ( ho \vec{V})}{\partial t} + \vec{ abla} \cdot ( ho \vec{V} \vec{V}) = ho \vec{g} + \vec{ abla} \cdot \sigma\] \[ rac{\partial ( ho v_j)}{\partial t} + rac{\partial }{\partial x_i}( ho v_j v_i) = ho g_j + rac{\partial \sigma_{ij}}{\partial x_i}\] \[ egin{align*} rac{\partial( ho u)}{\partial t} + rac{\partial( ho uu)}{\partial x} + rac{\partial ( ho uv)}{\partial y} + rac{\partial ( ho uw)}{\partial z} &= ho g_x + rac{\partial \sigma_{xx}}{\partial x} + rac{\sigma_{yx}}{\partial y} + rac{\sigma_{zx}}{\partial z}\ rac{\partial ( ho v)}{\partial t } + rac{\partial ( ho u v)}{\partial x } + rac{\partial ( ho v v)}{\partial y} + rac{\partial ( ho v w)}{\partial z}&= ho g_y + rac{\partial \sigma_{xy}}{\partial x} + rac{\sigma_{yy}}{\partial y} + rac{\sigma_{zy}}{\partial z}\ rac{\partial ( ho w)}{\partial t} + rac{\partial ( ho u w)}{\partial x} + rac{\partial( ho v w)}{\partial y} + rac{\partial ( ho w w)}{\partial z}&= ho g_z + rac{\partial \sigma_{xz}}{\partial x} + rac{\sigma_{yz}}{\partial y} + rac{\sigma_{zz}}{\partial z} \end{align*}\]

Cauchy’s equation - expanded

The left-hand side of the above equation can be replaced, and the Cauchy stress tensor expanded into isotropic and anisotropic components as follows. We haven’t made any major assumptions yet.

\[ ho rac{D\vec{V}}{Dt} = - \vec{ abla} P + \vec{ abla} \cdot au + ho \vec{g}\] \[ ho rac{D v_j}{Dt} = - rac{\partial P}{\partial x_j} + rac{\partial au_{ij}}{\partial x_i} + ho g_j\] \[ egin{align*} ho rac{D u}{Dt}&= - rac{\partial P}{\partial x} + rac{\partial au_{xx}}{\partial x}+ rac{\partial au_{yx}}{\partial y}+ rac{\partial au_{zx}}{\partial z} + ho g_x\ ho rac{D v}{Dt}&= - rac{\partial P}{\partial y} + rac{\partial au_{xy}}{\partial x}+ rac{\partial au_{yy}}{\partial y}+ rac{\partial au_{zy}}{\partial z} + ho g_y\ ho rac{D w}{Dt}&= - rac{\partial P}{\partial z} + rac{\partial au_{xz}}{\partial x}+ rac{\partial au_{yz}}{\partial y}+ rac{\partial au_{zz}}{\partial z} + ho g_z\ \end{align*}\]

Compressible Navier-Stokes equations

Assuming \(\mu\) is constant, and a Newtonian fluid, we get the compressible Navier-Stokes equations:

\[ ho rac{D\vec{V}}{Dt} = - \vec{ abla} P + \mu abla^2 \vec{V} + frac{1}{3}\mu \vec{ abla}(\vec{ abla}\cdot\vec{V}) + ho \vec{g}\] \[ ho rac{D v_j}{Dt} = - rac{\partial P}{\partial x_j} + \mu rac{\partial^2v_j}{\partial x_i \partial x_i} + rac{1}{3}\mu rac{\partial^2 v_i}{\partial x_j \partial x_i} + ho g_j\] \[ egin{align*} ho rac{D u}{Dt} &= - rac{\partial P}{\partial x} + \mu \left( rac{\partial^2 u}{\partial x^2} + rac{\partial^2 u}{\partial y^2} + rac{\partial^2 u}{\partial z^2} ight) + rac{1}{3}\mu \left( rac{\partial^2 u}{\partial x^2} + rac{\partial^2 v}{\partial x \partial y} + rac{\partial^2 w}{\partial x \partial z} ight) + ho g_x\ ho rac{D v}{Dt} &= - rac{\partial P}{\partial y} + \mu \left( rac{\partial^2 v}{\partial x^2} + rac{\partial^2 v}{\partial y^2} + rac{\partial^2 v}{\partial z^2} ight) + rac{1}{3}\mu \left( rac{\partial^2 u}{\partial y\partial x} + rac{\partial^2 v}{\partial y^2} + rac{\partial^2 w}{\partial y \partial z} ight) + ho g_y\ ho rac{D w}{Dt} &= - rac{\partial P}{\partial z} + \mu \left( rac{\partial^2 w}{\partial x^2} + rac{\partial^2 w}{\partial y^2} + rac{\partial^2 w}{\partial z^2} ight) + rac{1}{3}\mu \left( rac{\partial^2 u}{\partial z \partial x} + rac{\partial^2 v}{\partial z \partial y} + rac{\partial^2 w}{\partial z^2} ight) + ho g_z \end{align*}\]

Incompressible Navier-Stokes equations

Assuming \(\mu\) is constant, \( ho\) is constant, and a Newtonian fluid, we get the incompressible Navier-Stokes equations:

\[ ho rac{D\vec{V}}{Dt} = - \vec{ abla} P + \mu abla^2 \vec{V} + ho \vec{g}\] \[ ho rac{D v_j}{Dt} = - rac{\partial P}{\partial x_j} + \mu rac{\partial^2v_j}{\partial x_i \partial x_i} + ho g_j\] \[ egin{align*} ho rac{D u}{Dt} &= - rac{\partial P}{\partial x} + \mu \left( rac{\partial^2 u}{\partial x^2} + rac{\partial^2 u}{\partial y^2} + rac{\partial^2 u}{\partial z^2} ight) + ho g_x\ ho rac{D v}{Dt} &= - rac{\partial P}{\partial y} + \mu \left( rac{\partial^2 v}{\partial x^2} + rac{\partial^2 v}{\partial y^2} + rac{\partial^2 v}{\partial z^2} ight) + ho g_y\ ho rac{D w}{Dt} &= - rac{\partial P}{\partial z} + \mu \left( rac{\partial^2 w}{\partial x^2} + rac{\partial^2 w}{\partial y^2} + rac{\partial^2 w}{\partial z^2} ight) + ho g_z \end{align*}\]

We can also write the incompressible Navier-Stokes equations in terms of kinematic viscosity \( u = \mu/ ho\):

\[ rac{D\vec{V}}{Dt} = - rac{1}{ u}\vec{ abla} P + u abla^2 \vec{V} + \vec{g}\] \[ rac{D v_j}{Dt} = - rac{1}{ u} rac{\partial P}{\partial x_j} + u rac{\partial^2v_j}{\partial x_i \partial x_i} + g_j\] \[ egin{align*} rac{D u}{Dt} &= - rac{1}{ u} rac{\partial P}{\partial x} + u \left( rac{\partial^2 u}{\partial x^2} + rac{\partial^2 u}{\partial y^2} + rac{\partial^2 u}{\partial z^2} ight) + g_x\ rac{D v}{Dt} &= - rac{1}{ u} rac{\partial P}{\partial y} + u \left( rac{\partial^2 v}{\partial x^2} + rac{\partial^2 v}{\partial y^2} + rac{\partial^2 v}{\partial z^2} ight) + g_y\ rac{D w}{Dt} &= - rac{1}{ u} rac{\partial P}{\partial z} + u \left( rac{\partial^2 w}{\partial x^2} + rac{\partial^2 w}{\partial y^2} + rac{\partial^2 w}{\partial z^2} ight) + g_z \end{align*}\]

If you find any errors in the above, please contact me (rmcconke@uwaterloo.ca) so that I can fix them. If you found this useful, please let me know!
